info.name: Neural Network
info.description: The complex nervous system that provides the neuronal environment including synaptic networks (neural circuits, neurotransmitter systems), glial support systems, and neural coordination networks. This environment demonstrates how individual neurons exist within hierarchical neural organization where network-level systems enable neuronal function through signal propagation, metabolic support, and synaptic coordination.

info.name: Synaptic Input Signals
info.description: External neurotransmitter signals from presynaptic neurons - demonstrates how neurons depend on network-level systems for information processing and signal integration

info.name: Glial Metabolic Support
info.description: Glucose and oxygen supply from astrocytes and vascular system - represents the nervous system's metabolic support network that delivers energy substrates to individual neurons

info.name: Synaptic Output Transmission
info.description: Action potential-dependent synaptic transmission including neurotransmitter release, synaptic vesicle fusion, and postsynaptic receptor activation - represents all signal transmission activities that enable neural communication

info.name: Neural Waste Management
info.description: External system that receives and processes metabolic waste from neuronal activity - demonstrates the circular nature of neural systems where waste products are processed by glial cells and vascular clearance

info.name: Neuron
info.description: The fundamental unit of neural information processing demonstrating specialized cellular architecture for electrical and chemical signaling. This neuron model shows how neural computation emerges from coordinated subsystem interactions optimized for rapid signal transmission. Following Mobus's 7-tuple framework, the neuron exhibits all system characteristics: components (organelles + neural structures), network (dendritic trees + axonal projections), governance (nuclear + cytoplasmic control), boundary (membrane + myelin), transformation (electrochemical signaling), history (synaptic plasticity), and time dynamics (millisecond responses). The neuron exemplifies how specialized cells maintain computational function through continuous energy transformation and information processing.

info.name: Neural Membrane
info.description: Specialized phospholipid bilayer optimized for electrical signaling with high density of voltage-gated ion channels. Contains embedded proteins for action potential generation, neurotransmitter receptors for signal integration, and maintains the critical ion gradients (Na+/K+) that power neural computation. The membrane's electrical properties create the excitability necessary for rapid information processing.

info.name: Dendritic Receptor Zones
info.description: Membrane regions containing neurotransmitter receptors and voltage-gated channels. Neurotransmitters bind and trigger postsynaptic potentials - showing how neurons integrate multiple synaptic inputs for computation.

interfaces.protocol: 1. Neurotransmitter binding → 2. Receptor conformational change → 3. Ion channel opening → 4. Postsynaptic potential generation → 5. Spatial-temporal integration

info.name: Glial Glucose Interface
info.description: Specialized membrane transporters (GLUT3) that facilitate high-affinity glucose transport optimized for neural energy demands. Essential for maintaining ATP levels during high-frequency firing - demonstrates neuronal dependence on specialized metabolic support.

interfaces.protocol: 1. Glucose recognition by GLUT3 → 2. High-affinity binding → 3. Conformational transport → 4. Cytoplasmic release → 5. Immediate glycolytic processing

info.name: Synaptic Terminal Release Zone
info.description: Specialized membrane regions containing synaptic vesicles and calcium-sensitive release machinery. Action potentials trigger vesicle fusion and neurotransmitter release for signal transmission to postsynaptic targets.

interfaces.protocol: 1. Action potential arrival → 2. Voltage-gated Ca²⁺ channel opening → 3. Ca²⁺ influx → 4. SNARE-mediated vesicle fusion → 5. Neurotransmitter release → 6. Vesicle recycling

info.name: Metabolic Waste Efflux
info.description: Membrane transport systems for removing metabolic byproducts including lactate, CO2, and protein aggregates. Maintains cellular homeostasis during high metabolic activity periods.

interfaces.protocol: 1. Metabolite accumulation detection → 2. Transporter activation → 3. Concentration gradient-driven efflux → 4. Glial uptake coordination → 5. Vascular clearance

info.name: Mitochondria
info.description: Highly abundant neuronal powerhouses producing ATP through oxidative phosphorylation to meet extreme energy demands of neural signaling. Neurons contain more mitochondria than most cell types, especially concentrated at synaptic terminals and nodes of Ranvier where energy demands peak. These organelles enable the high metabolic rate required for maintaining ion gradients and synaptic transmission.

info.name: Neural Mitochondrial Membrane
info.description: Cristae-rich inner membrane optimized for high ATP output required by neural activity. Contains enhanced electron transport chain density and specialized calcium buffering capabilities essential for synaptic function regulation.

info.name: Neural Energy Status Reporter
info.description: Specialized signaling reporting ATP:ADP ratios and calcium buffering status to optimize neural firing patterns and synaptic strength

interfaces.protocol: 1. ATP:ADP ratio monitoring → 2. Ca²⁺ buffering status assessment → 3. Metabolic signal generation → 4. Nuclear gene expression adjustment → 5. Synaptic efficacy modulation

info.name: Endoplasmic Reticulum
info.description: Extensive membrane network specialized for synthesis of synaptic proteins, neurotransmitter receptors, and ion channels. Neural ER shows enhanced protein folding capacity and calcium storage functions critical for synaptic plasticity and signal transmission. Demonstrates how neural manufacturing is optimized for communication molecule production.

info.name: Neural ER Membrane
info.description: Continuous with nuclear envelope forming integrated protein synthesis system specialized for neural proteins. Enhanced ribosome density for producing synaptic vesicle proteins, neurotransmitter receptors, and voltage-gated ion channels.

info.name: Synaptic Protein Status Channel
info.description: Specialized communication reporting synthesis rates of synaptic proteins, ion channels, and neurotransmitter receptors to coordinate neural plasticity

interfaces.protocol: 1. Protein synthesis monitoring → 2. Folding success assessment → 3. ER stress detection → 4. Synaptic protein quality control → 5. Plasticity-related gene expression adjustment

info.name: Golgi Apparatus
info.description: Specialized protein processing center for synaptic vesicle formation and neurotransmitter packaging. Functions as the neuron's 'synaptic preparation center' - receiving, modifying, and packaging proteins into synaptic vesicles for neurotransmitter storage and release. Critical for maintaining synaptic transmission capacity.

info.name: Neural Golgi Complex
info.description: Specialized cisternae stacks for processing synaptic proteins and forming synaptic vesicles. Enhanced vesicle budding capacity for producing the thousands of synaptic vesicles required for neurotransmitter release.

info.name: Synaptic Vesicle Production Control
info.description: Receives regulatory signals from nucleus controlling synaptic vesicle production rates and neurotransmitter packaging based on synaptic activity demands

interfaces.protocol: 1. Synaptic activity assessment → 2. Vesicle production demand calculation → 3. Neurotransmitter synthesis coordination → 4. Vesicle trafficking regulation → 5. Synaptic strength optimization

info.name: Nucleus
info.description: Neural command center containing DNA with specialized gene expression programs for synaptic plasticity, neurotransmitter synthesis, and ion channel regulation. Demonstrates activity-dependent transcription where synaptic activity drives genetic programs that modify neural connectivity and computational properties. The nucleus integrates electrical and chemical signals to coordinate long-term neural adaptations.

info.name: Neural Nuclear Envelope
info.description: Double membrane with specialized nuclear pores optimized for rapid transport of activity-dependent transcription factors. Enables tight coupling between synaptic activity and gene expression for neural plasticity.

info.name: Activity-Dependent Transcription Sensor
info.description: Receives synaptic activity patterns and metabolic signals from neural subsystems to coordinate plasticity-related gene expression

interfaces.protocol: 1. Synaptic activity pattern detection → 2. Transcription factor activation → 3. Plasticity gene expression → 4. Protein synthesis coordination → 5. Synaptic strength modification

info.name: Neural Protein Production Controller
info.description: Receives protein synthesis status and coordinates production of synaptic proteins, ion channels, and neurotransmitter synthesis enzymes

interfaces.protocol: 1. Protein demand assessment → 2. Synthesis capacity evaluation → 3. Gene expression adjustment → 4. Ribosome allocation → 5. Protein quality monitoring

info.name: Neural Energy Coordinator
info.description: Receives metabolic state information to coordinate energy-dependent neural processes including synaptic transmission and plasticity

interfaces.protocol: 1. Energy state monitoring → 2. Metabolic gene expression → 3. Mitochondrial biogenesis → 4. Synaptic energy allocation → 5. Firing pattern optimization

info.name: Synaptic Vesicle Production Regulator
info.description: Sends regulatory signals controlling synaptic vesicle production and neurotransmitter synthesis based on activity patterns

interfaces.protocol: 1. Activity pattern analysis → 2. Synaptic demand calculation → 3. Vesicle production signals → 4. Neurotransmitter synthesis regulation → 5. Synaptic efficacy optimization

info.name: Dendritic Spines
info.description: Specialized postsynaptic structures that compartmentalize calcium signaling and enable synaptic plasticity. These demonstrate neural specialization for information processing through structural modifications that adjust synaptic strength based on activity patterns. Essential for learning and memory through activity-dependent morphological changes.

info.name: Spine Membrane
info.description: Specialized membrane neck structure that creates biochemical compartmentalization for calcium signaling and synaptic plasticity mechanisms. Enables local synaptic modifications without affecting neighboring synapses.

info.name: Plasticity Signal Generator
info.description: Communication pathway reporting synaptic activity patterns and calcium signaling events to nuclear transcriptional control

interfaces.protocol: 1. Synaptic activity detection → 2. Calcium signal integration → 3. Plasticity threshold assessment → 4. Transcription factor activation → 5. Nuclear signal transmission

info.name: Neurotransmitter Signals
info.description: Chemical neurotransmitters (glutamate, GABA, dopamine, acetylcholine) carrying encoded information from presynaptic neurons. These molecules bind to specific receptors and generate electrical responses, enabling complex neural computation through chemical-electrical signal conversion.

info.name: Neural Glucose (C₆H₁₂O₆)
info.description: High-priority glucose supply for neural metabolism. Neurons consume ~20% of body's glucose despite being ~2% of body weight, demonstrating extreme energy demands of neural computation. Essential for maintaining ion gradients and synaptic transmission.

info.name: Action Potentials
info.description: Electrical signals encoding neural information through precise timing and frequency patterns. Generated by coordinated ion channel activity and propagated along axons at speeds up to 120 m/s, enabling rapid neural communication across brain networks.

info.name: Neural Metabolic Waste
info.description: Metabolic byproducts from neural activity including lactate, ammonia, and protein aggregates. High neural metabolic rate produces significant waste requiring specialized glial clearance mechanisms and lymphatic drainage during sleep.

info.name: Synaptic Protein Status Signals
info.description: Molecular messages reporting synthesis rates of synaptic proteins, ion channels, and receptors. These signals enable nuclear coordination of protein production with synaptic activity demands for optimal neural function.

info.name: Plasticity Activity Patterns
info.description: Reports on synaptic activity patterns, calcium signaling events, and structural changes in dendritic spines. High-frequency activity triggers gene expression programs for long-term potentiation and synaptic strengthening.

info.name: Neural Energy Status
info.description: ATP:ADP ratios, calcium buffering capacity, and mitochondrial function status that inform nuclear control about cellular energy state. Critical for coordinating neural firing patterns with metabolic capacity.

info.name: Vesicle Production Commands
info.description: Regulatory signals from nucleus controlling synaptic vesicle synthesis, neurotransmitter packaging, and vesicle trafficking based on synaptic activity demands and plasticity requirements.
